column3: We've collected 536 climate plans. 2 still to look for. Keep up the great work! Have you looked and not found anything? Put an X here so we don't keep looking for the same plans
column4: Your name or twitter handle (not required) - just for credit!
column5:
URL of the council's action plan - this is the most important thing to collect! 

If you find more than one plan, add another row for the council for each plan and fill in the 'what kind of plan is this' column for each one if you can. 

All the plans need to cover the present day
column6: When did you retrieve this plan?
column7: What time period does it cover? e.g. 2020-2030?
column8: What kind of plan is this? Climate strategy / summary document / pre-plan (plan for making an action plan) / action plan / agenda minutes with links to lots of appendices
column9: What's the scope of this document? Does it just cover the council's own emissions or the emissions for both the council and the whole area?
column10: What's the status of this plan? Draft / interim / proposal / approved
column11: Does the council mention environment/climate action/sustainability on their homepage?
column12: Is there a page decidated to this with a link to their plan thats easy to find?
column13:
Is this well-presented for public understanding?
e.g. Is it a set of appendices to a council meeting minutes document, or a standalone document with some introduction to the context
column14: Is there a baseline analysis of the CO2 emissions in the area?
column15: Notes
column16: When is the full action plan due if there isn't one yet?

column18: title checked (mark with Y if checked)

column10: Draft. Still only a draft after 12 months; approved by the Cabinet in March 2020, but that means little (the whole council declared an emergency in March 2019).
column13: No, the papers for the Cabinet meeting (plus its two appendices) need to be processed via the council's PR dept in order to make make it glossy and appear impressive for public consumption.
column14: Haringey has been publishing annual carbon reports for some years. The goal of reducing carbon emissions Borough-wide was quietly dropped and replaced by the far smaller goal of reducing emissions from council-owned buildings. Thus, any sale of council buildings would flatter their figures. The council claims that they will meet their goal—"40:20" of several years ago—of achieving a 40% reduction in emissions by 2020. (if this is true, then it is true for council buildings only).
column15:
Haringey's "action plan" is admitted to be only a draft. It re-states the importance of the issue and talks at length about the council's ambition. It is three months overdue and comes 12 months after the council unanimously declared a Climate Emergency (in March 2019). There is no action in the plan. There will be no action before November 2020 at the earliest. In any event, it is moot as to whether the current Administration is capable of undertaking any action after then (i.e. after COP26).

Haringey did produce an impressive document setting out their ambitions, "Going Green: Haringey’s Greenest Borough Strategy". The difficulty is that this was published 11 (eleven) years ago: http://opinion8.ning.com/forum/topics/climate-change-and-haringey-council
column16: No earlier than November 2020. Although the PR function is likely to produce publications saying how well the council is doing, it is unlikely Haringey will take meaningful action.

column15: https://climatescience.blogspot.com/2019/09/no-climate-emergency-recommended-in-new.html "Whilst the Panel recognises that other Councils have declared a climate emergency, this Council can achieve more on a local level through the development of an environment action plan, with the ambition of achieving a carbon neutral position for the New Forest District Council by 2050.  Once developed, the action plan should give prominence within the Council’s Corporate Plan to ensure that environmental issues, including climate change, are taken into account in future decision making."
